description:
Glossina morsitans morsitans, commonly known as the savanna tsetse fly, is a subspecies of the tsetse fly. Tsetse flies are a group of biting flies found in sub-Saharan Africa, known for their role in transmitting trypanosomiasis, a disease that affects both humans and livestock.

Glossina morsitans morsitans is a member of the Glossinidae family and is one of the most widely distributed tsetse fly subspecies in Africa. It is primarily found in the savanna regions of central and southern Africa, including countries such as Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, and parts of Tanzania and Mozambique.

These tsetse flies are typically dark brown or gray in color, with a distinctive elongated body and large, transparent wings. They are approximately 8-14 millimeters in length and have a piercing-sucking mouthpart that they use to feed on the blood of various vertebrate hosts, including humans, livestock, and wild animals.

Glossina morsitans morsitans plays a significant role in the epidemiology of African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in livestock. The flies can transmit the parasitic protozoa Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, which cause the disease in humans, as well as Trypanosoma congolense and Trypanosoma vivax, which affect livestock.

The biology and ecology of Glossina morsitans morsitans are well-studied, as understanding the behavior and habitat preferences of this subspecies is crucial for developing effective control strategies against the tsetse fly and the diseases it transmits.
